webTitle: US unemployment rate falls to 5.9%; but wage growth disappoints - business live

fields.bodyText: After the recent slump in share prices - the FTSE 100 for example was at a near 10 month low on Thursday - investors were cautiously tipping their toes back in the water. The worries which have hit markets hard - signs of economic weakness around the world, a disappointing update from the ECB, protests in Hong Kong, air strikes on Isis, trouble in Ukraine and concerns about the spread of ebola - have not gone away. But many investors clearly felt the falls had gone too far. The more positive mood was helped by the US revealing a better than expected non-farm payroll figure, with 248,000 jobs added in September compared to expectations of 215,000. July and August figures were also revised upwards. So the final scores showed: The FTSE 100 finished 81.52 points or 1.26% higher at 6527.91 France’s Cac climbed 0.92% to 4281.74 Italy’s FTSE MIB added 1.54% to 20,200.62 Spain’s Ibex ended 1.44% at 10,567.6 Germany’s Dax was closed for unity day In the US, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 168 points or 1% higher. On that note it’s time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, have a good weekend, and we’ll be back on Monday. George Osborne has caused a stir by telling businessmen at the Institute of Directors’ conference to counter what he sees as an anti-free market movement led by trade unions and charities. Katie Allen reports: Speaking to business leaders at the Institute of Directors’ annual convention, Osborne said principles of enterprise and business as a force for widespread prosperity were “up for grabs” for the first time in his adult life. Osborne told the audience at London’s Royal Albert Hall: “You have to get out there and put the business argument. Because there are plenty of pressure groups, plenty of trade unions and plenty of charities and the like, that will put the counter view. Katie’s full story is here. And she has asked the TUC to comment on Osborne’s remarks: TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady said: “The Chancellor accuses unions of being anti-business, yet many of Britain’s most successful companies and sectors – such as car-makers – depend on the labour and skills of trade unionists just as much as their managers. He has let down his guard to show how much he agrees with Margaret Thatcher’s ‘enemy within’ rhetoric. “But the real issue today is that the Chancellor is doing nothing to fairly share the benefits of recovery. He has rewarded soaraway executive pay with tax cuts for the super-rich, but been happy to see the longest and deepest cut in living standards for everyone else, only this week announcing cuts in the benefits that low paid workers desperately need when the real value of their pay is falling.” And some comments from delegates at the IoD on Andy Street’s comments about France, courtesy of Katie Allen: John Rider, a turnaround expert from the West Midlands, who knows Street from local business alliances, felt the comments on France were out of character. “I have got a lot of time for Andy but I am surprised at his comments on France,” said Rider, a former regional chairman for the IoD in the West Midlands. “But I understand. It is difficult to do business [in France] and some of the protection of people is rigid and stops you making any change.” “If you employ people in France you are trapped for donkey’s years by red tape, bureaucracy, people and they seem pretty comfortable about it.” Another delegate, who happens to be French, thinks Street has overlooked the might of some important French sectors, not least luxury goods. “L’Oreal is still number one in the world. John Lewis actually sells a lot of French products,” says Veronique Raynaud, who has lived in London for 16 years. “John Lewis is probably doing very well from all the French community living near Sloane Square and buying French products.” “You can make comments on policies of government, on taxes, but can you make a comment on not investing in a country? It’s a bit of a blanket comment to make. It’s not very informed.” Others were sympathetic to Street’s follow up claim that his comments on France were “tongue in cheek”. “We have all made mistakes and he’s not an expert on the French economy. He may have had a lapse of the tongue,” said one conference delegate, who – perhaps taking a PR lesson from Street’s faux-pas – declined to be named. Meanwhile the founder of Uber has provided the Institute of Directors with a different take on what people like Andy Street see as France’s shortcomings, writes Katie Allen: Travis Kalanick, chief executive of the taxi app company, tells the conference Uber was born in Paris. “I like to say we were founded in Paris,” he says. He doesn’t go near what may or may not have been tongue in cheek comments from John Lewis boss Street, but Kalanick recounts being in the French capital with his co-founder. “We couldn’t get a taxi... I don’t know if you have ever tried to get a taxi in Paris... my co-founder said I wish I could push a button and get a ride.” Some say sclerotic. Some say the mother of invention... Back with the comments on France from John Lewis managing director Andy Street. As a reminder he said, among other things, that France was “sclerotic, hopeless and downbeat” and said the Gare du Nord was “the squalor pit of Europe”. My colleague Katie Allen is at the Institute of Directors’ annual meeting and has been talking to its director general Simon Walker. She reports: Walker told the Guardian that Street’s remarks had taken him aback a little but he sympathised with concerns about the French economy: “I’m a little surprised. I have a house in France and spend as much time as I can in France… the wine is better, the people are stylish… I even quite like Gard du Nord. “The French economy is a disaster area and I think his analysis is basically right. “I have certainly worked in companies that wouldn’t invest in France because of its rigid and inflexible labour market… France is protectionist and protectionism is something that has to be fought.” But he said it was wrong to think of France as devoid of economic dynamism. “There are many entrepreneurs in France.” As for how France compares to its neighbours, Walker added: “Sclerotic is a legitimate word to use with regard to France and other parts of the eurozone as well.” Aside from freeing up labour in France, the country should also reduce its government spending as a share of GDP, currently an “unsustainable” 58%, Walker said. He would not take Street’s lead in recommending people take investments out of France, Walker said. “I think you invest where you can find open markets and that’s always a bit of a myth with France, because this is the country that blocked the takeover of a yoghurt company,” Walker said, referring to the government’s blocking of a buyout of Danone in 2005. But he would not tell IoD members where to do business. “I think we should trade wherever we can. We have people who export to North Korea. Don’t give up hope on anywhere,” Walker concluded. Jean Claude Juncker, the EU’s president designate has held lunchtime talks with Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras during his flying visit to Athens. The meeting - at the Benaki Museum in Athens - took place in “a very good climate” according to local media. Helena Smith reports: The visit was aimed at concentrating minds on reform efforts Greece has to make as mission chiefs representing the country’s troika of creditors at the EU, ECB and IMF, conduct a fifth review of the Greek economy with government ministers in Athens. Greek media reports said that the incoming president was also keen to discuss “the post-bailout [memorandum] Greece” as the country prepares to exit its €240bn international financial support programme. Over the working lunch with Samaras, Juncker focused specifically on Greece’s desire to disengage from the Washington-based IMF, whose disbursement of aid instalments was originally not due to end until March 2016 (unlike euro area countries whose support for the debt-stricken nation expires this year). In a move that took many aback, Samaras announced the end of the “memorandum period” for Greece during talks with the German chancellor Angela Merkel last week, saying that Athens would seek to end engagement with the IMF “early.” The leader, who earlier this week announced he would seek a vote of confidence in his government next week, has said that it is now vital that Greece ends oversight by foreign lenders and takes ownership of its own reform/modernisation programme almost five years after seeking international aid to avoid bankruptcy. Juncker, readers of this blog will recall, is a hardened “hellenophile” and one of the strongest supporters of Greece throughout the eurozone crisis when as euro group chairman he was in charge of much EU policy towards the country. If the US non-farm payroll numbers are better than expected, then the just-released service sector for September has shown a dip from August. The services sector purchasing managers index fell to 58.9 from 59.5, but up from an earlier flash reading for September of 58.5. Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit, said: A slowing in the pace of service sector growth in September matched a similar easing in the pace of manufacturing output growth seen during the month, suggesting the overall pace of economic expansion dipped to the weakest since May. But this has not stopped the US market - and indeed European ones - from rebounding from recent weakness. In early trading the Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 143 points or 0.85%. A US interest rate rise in the second quarter is looking increasingly unlikely, according to Rob Carnell of ING. He said: There were some elements in this release for the doves to cling on to. Wages growth, despite anecdotes of strong hiring, labour shortages and building wage pressure, slipped back to 2.0% year on year from 2.1%, on a 0.0% month on month change. This is disappointing. That said, with oil prices plunging, and headline inflation in the US likely to fall sharply in coming months, thoughts of a second quarter 2015 rate hike from the Fed are looking increasingly unlikely, so wages are less of a pivot for policy-makers than they were several months ago when CPI inflation was pushing above 2.0%. Alastair Winter, chief economist at Daniel Stewart (the boutique investment bank), says Fed chief Janet Yellen will worry that wages aren’t rising faster, and the other downbeat elements to the report. But that may not stop rates rising in the first half of next year. Alistair writes: “Welcome as the drop in the unemployment rate is, I very much doubt it will make much difference to the FOMC in its march towards the first rate hike in March or June 2015. The kindly Ms Yellen will wring her hands over the stubbornly high numbers of long-term unemployed, the part-timers wanting to be full-time and the ‘discouraged workers.’ The realistic Ms Yellen will fret more over the slow growth of average earnings and the sticky participation rate. Then she will conclude there is not much more she can do about any of them.” Marc Ostwald of ADM Investor Services, says the drop in the US jobless rate is a relief after various weaker data recently. Here’s his take on the non-farm report: Key points: a) Payrolls: a solid beat at +248k vs. expected 215K, with August revised up by 38K, and July up by 31K Positives: 1) Government jobs increase +12K Disappointments: 1) gain paced by Services +207K, notably Retail +35K 2) Leisure/Hospitality +33K, so a continued lack of breadth: 3) Manufacturing just +4K with August revised down to -4K b) Unemployment Rate: down to 5.9% from 6.1% will be grist to the mill for the Fed hawks, but the doves will note that the Underemployment Rate at 11.8% while falling from 12.0% is still far too high, especially at this stage of the cycle, though +232K rise in Employment encouraging,though offset by fresh low on the Participation Rate at 62.7% from 62.8% c) Average Hourly Earnings: soft at Flat m/m 2.0% y/y - though given that the Payrolls gains were paced by lower paid services jobs, this should not come any surprise. d) Average Weekly Hours: Hoorah the headline reading at 34.6 has finally broken the 34.5 ceiling that has been in place since 2012, though Manufacturing Hours only marginally higher - again unsurprising given Manufacturing payrolls. With America’s jobless rate now the lowest since summer 2008, there is more pressure on the Fed to normalise monetary policy. So reckons Marcus Bullus, trading director of MB Capital: “After this robust number, and decent upward revisions for both July and August, the hawks will once again be circling. “Policymakers will also be encouraged by the fall in the number of discouraged workers. More people are starting to believe in the economy again and that matters a lot. However, there’s no avoiding the fact that wages aren’t rising faster: “Anaemic wage growth continues to be the major conundrum facing markets and policymakers alike. “You’d expect to see wages rising with more gusto in an improving jobs market, but this just isn’t happening. These two tweets sum up the non-farm payroll: As the dollar strengthens, the gold price takes another tumble: The dollar is surging, as traders calculate that the fall in the US unemployment rate will prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates before too long. It has gained over a cent against the pound, to $1.6006. The initial reaction in the financial markets is that this is a strong jobs report. The other disappointment is that America’s labor force participation rate has fallen again, from 62.8% to 62.7%. That shows that more people have dropped out of the workforce altogether, which helped to drag the overall jobless rate down to 5.9% [because it measures the proportion of people who could be in work, but aren’t] But there is disappointment too - today’s non-farm payroll shows no change in average hourly earnings in September compared with August. That suggests that the recovery isn’t really feeding into American’s wage packets. Wall Street economists had been hoping for a 0.2% increase month-on-month. That left wages 2.0% higher than a year ago. More good news, last month’s weak non-farm payroll report has been revised higher. It now shows that 180,000 new jobs were created in August, not the 142,000 first estimated. And July’s NFP is higher too - up to 243k, from 212k before. BREAKING: The US non-farm payroll shows that 248,000 new jobs were created across America last month. That’s a stronger reading than expected. And the US unemployment rate has fallen to 5.9%, which is the lowest since July 2008. But it’s not all good news --- the labour force participation rate is a little lower, and average earnings are unchanged. Lots more details to follow.... Right, time for the last major piece of economic news of the week (hurrah!) The US non-farm payroll is announced in a few moments, showing how many new jobs were created in America last month. And economists expect a reading of at least 200,000.... Andy Street’s comments about the French economy have already caused a stink in Paris, where a deputy mayor called them “false and idiotic”. Our correspondent Kim Willsher reports: Jean-Louis Missika, a deputy Paris mayor in charge of economic development and the attractiveness of Paris to investors, told The Guardian that if Andy Street was joking, perhaps Paris should respond in kind. “What he says is false and idiotic. As we say, everything excessive is exaggerated, but then it seems French bashing is all the fashion chez vous. “Factually it’s false because figures show that last year Paris attracted more foreign investment than London, and because Paris is a dynamic city with a quality of service that is often better than in London.” John Lewis’s managing director, Andy Street, has apologised unreservedly for his comments about France. In a statement, Street said: “The remarks I made were supposed to be lighthearted views, and tongue in cheek. On reflection I clearly went too far. I regret the comments, and apologise unreservedly”. As covered earlier (and all over the UK press), Street describing France as “sclerotic, hopeless and downbeat”. He made the comments at an event in London, following a trip to Paris where he received a retail award that was “made of plastic and is frankly revolting”. ITV’s Joel Hills is reporting that John Lewis’s MD has now apologised for his French gaffe: The bold declaration by John Lewis’s MD that France was in decline and “finished” continues to reverberate around the media today. Over on FT Alphaville, Bryce Elder was tickled by Andy Street’s description of Gare du Nord as a “squalid” railway station. Such a contrast with Britain’s own architectural heritage, eh?: When not doing his bit for Entente cordiale, Bryce also got the City excited by discussing rumours that Tesco might need to raise £3bn from its own shareholders. We can say with a degree of certainty that a rights issue, £3bn ish probably, is among the options being considered. That sent Tesco’s shares down another 4.5%; a spokesperson has now said there are “no current plans” for a rights issue. No mention of future plans, of course.... The Institute of Directors had hoping to hear from Alex Salmond at today’s annual conference. But after the Scottish first minister pulled out, organisers called in Peter Kellner, president of pollsters YouGov, to cover all things Scottish referendum. And he spoke about how public trust in those in power, including business people, has been eroded. From the Hall, Katie Allen reports: Kellner talked about the vote on Scottish independence but also had a message for the audience of business leaders. Providing some welcome context for George Osborne’s earlier complaints about the rise of an anti-business movement, Kellner flagged up the dwindling reputations of those in power - be it in central government, local government or business. There had been a marked decline in recent years of trust in politics, driven by the weapons of mass destruction (WMD) revelations (or lack thereof) and later on the expenses scandal. But YouGov had also noted that the reputation of business leaders had declined as a group by tracking various figures in positions of power, Kellner said. He told the audience that people picked politicians largely based questions around apparent characteristics such as “are they self-serving or public spirited?” Similarly, businesses must ask themselves how their behaviour plays out in public. If they are judged by stories of “zero-hours, bad pay for cleaners, bad treatment of people in China and Bangladesh... bonuses that appear unforgiveable, tax arrangements that are not ... sociable ... these play like the WMD story on reputations,” Kellner warned. George Osborne’s broad message to the Institute of Directors this morning is that stability and tax cuts go hand in hand. He was speaking just two days after PM David Cameron promised billions of pounds of income tax cuts if the Conservatives win the next election. But that’s not guaranteed. Political expert Peter Kellner told IoD members that next May’s poll could deliver another coalition. Asked about the UK government’s push for reforms in the European Union, Osborne sought to emphasise it was not an entirely selfless project. The chancellor declared: “We want economic reform in Europe not just for ourselves but for the French, the Spanish [and other countries too]. “We do it not just for ourselves but because we want to live in a prosperous economy,” he said. On the subject of immigration, increasingly linked in British political debate to the European Union, Osborne appeared to sympathise with some voters’ concerns. “Free movement of people was never envisaged as freedom to move and claim benefits.” “It’s important that we find a way through this... there are very real concerns of many members of the British public.” The IoD, though, is concerned that the clampdown on free movement could hurt the economy, as their head of Europe and trade policy Allie Renison flags up: Osborne ended with a plea to business to take a stand in what he sees as a new wrangle over the role of enterprise in society. “That issue felt like it had been resolved when the Berlin wall fell,” he says. “I would urge the business community not to stand on the sidelines.” And – preaching to the choir somewhat – he told the audience to put the “business argument” against the trade unions, charities and others who - Osborne believed - question the role of business. Osborne’s own vision is of a business-friendly “low tax economy that delivers prosperity for people for generations to come.” There endeth the lesson from the Book of Capitalists..... Asked by an IoD member from the West Midlands about why the UK still struggled to grow exports, George Osborne said problems in the eurozone, a key market, were a short-term challenge and longer term small and medium sized businesses needed to look further afield. “Very, very weak growth in the eurozone” is the “biggest near-term risk”, he told the Annual Conference. Long-term, “we have not connected ourselves enough with the fast growing economies in Asia and the like.” He said small and medium sized business in the UK appeared “too daunted” about launching into new markets, not the case for small and medium sized businesses in Germany. For its part, the government has expanded UKTI, he said, and was taking cues from business rather than seeking to come up with export policies out of Whitehall. “But I am the first to say we have more work to do in this space.” George Osborne also promised that Westminster will meet its pledge to Scotland’s oil and gas industry.... ...even if he’s a bit vague on the details. The eurozone remains the biggest threat to the UK recovery, Osborne says (perhaps he was thinking of this morning’s poor PMI surveys...) George Osborne is explaining to the IoD annual conferenve how the raft of measures announced this week add up (Katie Allen writes) The chancellor lays out three points he sees as key to the party’s policies. Firstly, stability and reassurance that the deficit will come down is crucial, especially for businesses. “We have got to reduce the deficit which is still too high” and so he has announced things you would not normally hear ahead of an election, he says, such as a benefits freeze. Secondly, the Conservatives “unashamedly put business at the heart of our political message.” Hence competitive business tax rates, he says. Thirdly, “we have got to make work pay ... That the system works for hard working people, making sure people pay less tax, people on low pay are taken out of tax” and that there is help for people on middle incomes too. Overall, he says, the government has showed: “we can achieve both those things, economic stability and low taxes.” Simon Walker, IoD director-general, is introducing George Osborne at the Institute of Directors annual conference now. Walker says the theme of this year’s business jamboree is “game changer” (reports my colleague Katie Allen from the conference). Walker says much has changed since last year’s meeting, including the creation of half a million jobs and stronger growth than most other advanced economies. But it is also a year when the country almost broke apart. Part of the reason for that is some people are feeling the effects of the recession rather than the recovery from recession, he says. Walker also urges members to make sure that business gets across the message that is a force for good.... Heads-up... UK chancellor George Osborne has begun speaking at the Institute of Director’s Annual Convention..... John Lewis, the retail chain, is in the spotlight this morning after its managing director described France as “sclerotic, hopeless and downbeat”. Andy Street urged British entrepreneurs to flee the country while there’s time, declaring: If you’ve got investments in French businesses, get them out quickly.” Street also blasted the Gare du Nord as the “squalor pit of Europe” (?!), in remarks which The Times reckons were ‘tongue in cheek’. ‘Head in hands’ might be more appropriate. More here: John Lewis boss: ‘France is sclerotic, hopeless and downbeat … it’s finished’ The UK services PMI report suggests that Britain’s economy grew by around 0.8% in the third quarter of this year, according to Markit’s Chris Williamson. He reckons the economy is ‘moderating’, after several strong quarters: “September’s PMI surveys suggest that the UK most likely enjoyed another spell of above-trend economic growth in the third quarter, but the recovery appears to be losing its legs. “The PMI surveys are collectively signalling GDP growth of 0.8% in the third quarter, down from 0.9% in the three months to June but still strong by historical standards. However, the pace of expansion hit a six-month low in September and is showing signs of moderating further as we move towards the end of the year.” Here comes the UK data....and the news is that Britain’s dominant service sector recorded decent growth in September. But growth did slow a little, to its slowest in three months, and there are fears that the recent strong recovery is “losing its legs”. The UK services PMI dipped to a three month low last month, dropping to 58.7 from 60.5 in August. (50 is the cut-off point between expansion and contraction) Markit says that overall growth remains “sharp”, and the good news is that new business continued to increase. It adds: Capacity remained under pressure, with backlogs of work continuing to increase, and companies were suitably encouraged to add to their payroll numbers. Confidence in the future also helped to support payroll expansion, with latest data showing business expectations at a three-month high. September’s poor PMI surveys show that eurozone economic growth in the last quarter was weak, says Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit: “The PMI suggests the eurozone economy remained stuck in a rut in the third quarter. After GDP stagnated in the second quarter, we can only expect modest growth of 0.2-0.3% in the third quarter based on these survey readings, with momentum being lost as we head into the final quarter of the year. There are some pockets of growth: Ireland’s economy is recovering strongly, Spain is seeing a still-robust upturn and the German service sector is providing an important prop to growth in the region as a whole. But the overall picture is one of a euro area economy that is struggling against multiple headwinds. These include a lack of domestic demand in many countries, subdued bank lending, sanctions with Russia and a reluctance of companies to expand in the face of an uncertain economic outlook. And if things don’t improve, there will be more pressure on the European Central Bank to “broaden the scope of its planned asset purchases” to buy riskier assets and even sovereign debt, Williamson concludes. Here’s a reminder of this morning’s data: Europe’s economic woes have deepened, with private sector growth slowing to the lowest rate in 10 months. That’s the conclusions of this morning’s data, and surveys earlier this week. Markit’s Eurozone PMI composite output index, which tracks activity across thousands of firms, has fallen to a ten-month low of 52.0 in September, down from 52.5 in August. Markit pulls no punches, saying: The ongoing malaise in the eurozone economy continued at the end of the third quarter, with the latest PMI data showing a further waning of output and new order growth. As covered earlier in the blog, Italy (details) and France (details) are the two main worries. France saw solid declines in both manufacturing production and service sector activity. The contraction in Italy was centred on the service sector, as manufacturing output expanded. The data is also a blow to hopes that Europe’s employment crisis might be improving. Staffing levels fell at the steepest pace for 16 months in France. Job creation accelerated in Germany, but slowed in Ireland and Spain. Headcounts stabilised in Italy, following a slight decrease in August. Reaction to follow.... Germany’s service firms have defied the slowdown in France, Italy and Spain, with activity growing at a faster rate. The German services PMI rose to 55.7 in September, up from 54.9 in August, showing growth accelerated. Activity and new order growth picked up after dipping in August. But it’s not all good news. Confidence towards the business outlook among German firms falls to 15-month low. Markit’s Oliver Kolodseike says: companies expect the introduction of a national minimum wage in January 2015 to have at least some negative effect on economic growth. Russian sanctions and the weak eurozone economy may be a factor. France’s economy has moved deeper into trouble too. Its service sector contracted in September for the first time in three months, according to Markit, dragging the wider French private sector into contraction too. Service sector firms reported a fall in new business, and an increase in staff layoffs. Alarmingly, French service sector firms cut staffing levels at the sharpest rate in 17 months. Markit says: There were reports from the survey panel linking job losses to company restructuring policies and, in some cases, decisions not to replace voluntary leavers. Jack Kennedy, senior economist at Markit, adds: “September’s PMI data rounded off another disappointing quarter for the French private sector economy. Based on the survey’s activity readings, GDP still looks to be tracking close to stagnation, continuing the stalling performance seen since the start of the year. Jobs across the private sector were cut at the sharpest rate for 16 months in September, suggesting that companies are braced for a prolonged period of weakness.” And this is worrying too! Italy’s service sector suffered a deeper contraction than expected last month. Markit’s Italian services sector PMI fell to 48.8, down from August’s reading of 49.8. That shows a sharper drop in activity, indicating that Italy’s service sector remained in contraction at the end of the third quarter, Markit reports that new business fell, due to “a general weakening of client demand in September”. Phil Smith, economist at Markit, says the reading puts “another dent in the hopes of the [Italian] economy climbing out of recession in the third quarter”. “Weakness in demand was evident as new business intakes went down another notch, which in turn pressured businesses into making further notable reductions to their charges. Manufacturers likewise reduced their output prices, suggesting broad-based deflationary forces. “A halt in service sector job cuts and improved business sentiment were the relatively positive takeaways from the latest data, with the former a step in the right direction in terms of seeing demand-side trends improve.” Now this is worrying... growth in the Spanish service sector has slowed, and new orders grew at the lowest rate in almost a year. Spain’s recent revival tailed off last month, according to data firm Markit, with employment levels broadly unchanged. Its Spanish services PMI fell sharply to 55.8 in September from 58.1 in August; that still shows growth, but not as robust. It’s the slowest rise in activity for three months. Andrew Harker, senior economist at Markit, doesn’t sound too alarmed, predicting that Spain’s economy still grew solidly in the last quarter. But still.... “There were signs of a growth slowdown in the Spanish service sector at the end of Q3, particularly with regards to new business which increased at the weakest pace for almost a year. There was also disappointing news on the employment front, with the recent spell of job creation coming to an end. Russia’s private sector only managed to post small growth last month, according to HSBC’s survey of the sector. The Russian composite PMI slid to just 50.9, close to the 50-point mark showing stagnation. Firms reported falling optimism, with business expectations close to their lowest point since the financial crisis began. Employment levels fell for the 15th month running, and firms reported “weakening demand, a lack of funds among clients and weak international demand”. Alexander Morozov, HSBC’s chief economist for Russia, warned that the country is sliding into recession: Overall, the Russian economy must have continued very slow growth in September amid strong and intensified cost pressures and increasing uncertainties about future business development. Such weak mechanical growth is better than the absence of growth, but we do not see drivers for stronger growth while downside risks to growth are abundant. Lower oil prices and persistent decline in fixed investment are just few of them. A mild recession remains our base case scenario for the coming quarters. Here’s the full report. Ireland’s recovery from the depths of its austerity slump continues, with service sector firms reporting the 26th month of consecutive growth. Investec’s monthly PMI survey, based on interviews with purchasing managers at Irish firms, found that new business had expanded at its fastest since May 2006. Irish firms are also more confidence, with 60% expecting activity to rise in the next year. Philip O’Sullivan, Chief Economist at Investec Ireland, says Ireland is benefiting from the recovery in the UK economy: Panellists reported that the growth in New Business was a result of clients’ increased willingness to commit to new projects given signs of improvement in the Irish economy. Growth in New Export Business also accelerated during September, with the UK cited as a particular source of strength. The overall Service sector PMI rose to 62.5 in September, showing strong growth, after August’s 62.4. There’s gloomy news from China overnight -- its services sector has grown at the slowest pace in eight month, partly due to the weakening housing market. Official figures showed that new orders actually shrank in September, for the first time since the collapse of Lehman Brothers. The official non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) fell to 54.0 in September from 54.4 in August, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. That still shows growth, but the slowest since January, adding to concerns that the Chinese economy is slowing. Today’s report also shows that China’s real estate sector shrank in September, as did the aviation and logistics sectors. Cai Jin, the vice-chairman of China Federation of Logistics and Purchasing, reckons China’s property slide may have bottomed out: Business activities in the property market have stabilized at low levels but stayed within the contractionary area, suggesting overall activities remained sluggish.” Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, business and the eurozone. After yesterday’s nervy sell-off, Europe’s stock markets are expected to bounce back a little today as traders prepare for the latest US jobs report. September’s non-farm payroll, due at 1.30pm BST, is expected to show that hiring picked up again after just 142,000 or so new jobs were created in August. And a positive jobs report is likely to drive investors to conclude that the US Federal Reserve will move closer to its first interest rate hike since the crisis began. Stan Shamu, IG’s man in Melbourne, sets the scene: After recent comments by Fed members who increasingly sound more hawkish, this week’s non-farm payrolls data will carry significant weight and go a long way towards shaping rate hike expectations. After a slump the previous month (142,000), non-farm payrolls are expected to bounce back strongly with a reading north of 200,000. Analysts feel a strong reading today could then see the Fed drop its ‘considerable time’ reference as far as rates lift-off is concerned. This month’s FOMC meeting will also be when QE wraps up and therefore is likely to be pivotal for the greenback. In the meantime, we’ll be watching the latest service sector data from Europe for signs that the economy may be recovering. Economists expect to see the Italy and France’s service sectors both contracted again last month, while firms in Germany and the UK report stronger growth. We’ll have all the data by 9.30am BST.....
fields.standfirst:
Rolling business and financial news, as America’s jobs rate hits the lowest since July 2008.

  • Latest: Non-farm payroll grows by 248,000
fields.headline: US unemployment rate falls to 5.9%; but wage growth disappoints - business live
fields.body:
5.33pm BST

US jobs figures give boost to markets

After the recent slump in share prices - the FTSE 100 for example was at a near 10 month low on Thursday - investors were cautiously tipping their toes back in the water. The worries which have hit markets hard - signs of economic weakness around the world, a disappointing update from the ECB, protests in Hong Kong, air strikes on Isis, trouble in Ukraine and concerns about the spread of ebola - have not gone away. But many investors clearly felt the falls had gone too far. The more positive mood was helped by the US revealing a better than expected non-farm payroll figure, with 248,000 jobs added in September compared to expectations of 215,000. July and August figures were also revised upwards. So the final scores showed:

  • The FTSE 100 finished 81.52 points or 1.26% higher at 6527.91
  • France’s Cac climbed 0.92% to 4281.74
  • Italy’s FTSE MIB added 1.54% to 20,200.62
  • Spain’s Ibex ended 1.44% at 10,567.6
  • Germany’s Dax was closed for unity day

In the US, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 168 points or 1% higher.

On that note it’s time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, have a good weekend, and we’ll be back on Monday.

Updated at 6.02pm BST

4.30pm BST

George Osborne has caused a stir by telling businessmen at the Institute of Directors’ conference to counter what he sees as an anti-free market movement led by trade unions and charities. Katie Allen reports:

Speaking to business leaders at the Institute of Directors’ annual convention, Osborne said principles of enterprise and business as a force for widespread prosperity were “up for grabs” for the first time in his adult life.

Osborne told the audience at London’s Royal Albert Hall: “You have to get out there and put the business argument. Because there are plenty of pressure groups, plenty of trade unions and plenty of charities and the like, that will put the counter view.

Katie’s full story is here.

And she has asked the TUC to comment on Osborne’s remarks:

TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady said: “The Chancellor accuses unions of being anti-business, yet many of Britain’s most successful companies and sectors – such as car-makers – depend on the labour and skills of trade unionists just as much as their managers. He has let down his guard to show how much he agrees with Margaret Thatcher’s ‘enemy within’ rhetoric.

“But the real issue today is that the Chancellor is doing nothing to fairly share the benefits of recovery. He has rewarded soaraway executive pay with tax cuts for the super-rich, but been happy to see the longest and deepest cut in living standards for everyone else, only this week announcing cuts in the benefits that low paid workers desperately need when the real value of their pay is falling.”

3.37pm BST

And some comments from delegates at the IoD on Andy Street’s comments about France, courtesy of Katie Allen:

John Rider, a turnaround expert from the West Midlands, who knows Street from local business alliances, felt the comments on France were out of character.

“I have got a lot of time for Andy but I am surprised at his comments on France,” said Rider, a former regional chairman for the IoD in the West Midlands.

“But I understand. It is difficult to do business [in France] and some of the protection of people is rigid and stops you making any change.”

“If you employ people in France you are trapped for donkey’s years by red tape, bureaucracy, people and they seem pretty comfortable about it.”

Another delegate, who happens to be French, thinks Street has overlooked the might of some important French sectors, not least luxury goods.

“L’Oreal is still number one in the world. John Lewis actually sells a lot of French products,” says Veronique Raynaud, who has lived in London for 16 years.

“John Lewis is probably doing very well from all the French community living near Sloane Square and buying French products.”

“You can make comments on policies of government, on taxes, but can you make a comment on not investing in a country? It’s a bit of a blanket comment to make. It’s not very informed.”

Others were sympathetic to Street’s follow up claim that his comments on France were “tongue in cheek”.

“We have all made mistakes and he’s not an expert on the French economy. He may have had a lapse of the tongue,” said one conference delegate, who – perhaps taking a PR lesson from Street’s faux-pas – declined to be named.

Updated at 3.38pm BST

3.27pm BST

Meanwhile the founder of Uber has provided the Institute of Directors with a different take on what people like Andy Street see as France’s shortcomings, writes Katie Allen:

Travis Kalanick, chief executive of the taxi app company, tells the conference Uber was born in Paris.

“I like to say we were founded in Paris,” he says. He doesn’t go near what may or may not have been tongue in cheek comments from John Lewis boss Street, but Kalanick recounts being in the French capital with his co-founder.

“We couldn’t get a taxi... I don’t know if you have ever tried to get a taxi in Paris... my co-founder said I wish I could push a button and get a ride.”

Some say sclerotic. Some say the mother of invention...

3.22pm BST

Back with the comments on France from John Lewis managing director Andy Street. As a reminder he said, among other things, that France was “sclerotic, hopeless and downbeat” and said the Gare du Nord was “the squalor pit of Europe”.

My colleague Katie Allen is at the Institute of Directors’ annual meeting and has been talking to its director general Simon Walker. She reports:

Walker told the Guardian that Street’s remarks had taken him aback a little but he sympathised with concerns about the French economy:

“I’m a little surprised. I have a house in France and spend as much time as I can in France… the wine is better, the people are stylish… I even quite like Gard du Nord.

“The French economy is a disaster area and I think his analysis is basically right.

“I have certainly worked in companies that wouldn’t invest in France because of its rigid and inflexible labour market… France is protectionist and protectionism is something that has to be fought.”

But he said it was wrong to think of France as devoid of economic dynamism. “There are many entrepreneurs in France.”

As for how France compares to its neighbours, Walker added: “Sclerotic is a legitimate word to use with regard to France and other parts of the eurozone as well.”

Aside from freeing up labour in France, the country should also reduce its government spending as a share of GDP, currently an “unsustainable” 58%, Walker said.

He would not take Street’s lead in recommending people take investments out of France, Walker said.

“I think you invest where you can find open markets and that’s always a bit of a myth with France, because this is the country that blocked the takeover of a yoghurt company,” Walker said, referring to the government’s blocking of a buyout of Danone in 2005.

But he would not tell IoD members where to do business. “I think we should trade wherever we can. We have people who export to North Korea. Don’t give up hope on anywhere,” Walker concluded.

Updated at 4.32pm BST

2.59pm BST

EU president elect Juncker holds talks with Greek PM Samaras in Athens

Jean Claude Juncker, the EU’s president designate has held lunchtime talks with Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras during his flying visit to Athens.

The meeting - at the Benaki Museum in Athens - took place in “a very good climate” according to local media. Helena Smith reports:

The visit was aimed at concentrating minds on reform efforts Greece has to make as mission chiefs representing the country’s troika of creditors at the EU, ECB and IMF, conduct a fifth review of the Greek economy with government ministers in Athens.

Greek media reports said that the incoming president was also keen to discuss “the post-bailout [memorandum] Greece” as the country prepares to exit its €240bn international financial support programme.

Over the working lunch with Samaras, Juncker focused specifically on Greece’s desire to disengage from the Washington-based IMF, whose disbursement of aid instalments was originally not due to end until March 2016 (unlike euro area countries whose support for the debt-stricken nation expires this year).

In a move that took many aback, Samaras announced the end of the “memorandum period” for Greece during talks with the German chancellor Angela Merkel last week, saying that Athens would seek to end engagement with the IMF “early.” The leader, who earlier this week announced he would seek a vote of confidence in his government next week, has said that it is now vital that Greece ends oversight by foreign lenders and takes ownership of its own reform/modernisation programme almost five years after seeking international aid to avoid bankruptcy.

Juncker, readers of this blog will recall, is a hardened “hellenophile” and one of the strongest supporters of Greece throughout the eurozone crisis when as euro group chairman he was in charge of much EU policy towards the country.

Updated at 3.05pm BST

2.52pm BST

If the US non-farm payroll numbers are better than expected, then the just-released service sector for September has shown a dip from August.

The services sector purchasing managers index fell to 58.9 from 59.5, but up from an earlier flash reading for September of 58.5.

Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit, said:

A slowing in the pace of service sector growth in September matched a similar easing in the pace of manufacturing output growth seen during the month, suggesting the overall pace of economic expansion dipped to the weakest since May.

But this has not stopped the US market - and indeed European ones - from rebounding from recent weakness.

In early trading the Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 143 points or 0.85%.

2.41pm BST

A US interest rate rise in the second quarter is looking increasingly unlikely, according to Rob Carnell of ING. He said:

There were some elements in this release for the doves to cling on to. Wages growth, despite anecdotes of strong hiring, labour shortages and building wage pressure, slipped back to 2.0% year on year from 2.1%, on a 0.0% month on month change. This is disappointing.

That said, with oil prices plunging, and headline inflation in the US likely to fall sharply in coming months, thoughts of a second quarter 2015 rate hike from the Fed are looking increasingly unlikely, so wages are less of a pivot for policy-makers than they were several months ago when CPI inflation was pushing above 2.0%.

Updated at 2.53pm BST

2.24pm BST

Alastair Winter, chief economist at Daniel Stewart (the boutique investment bank), says Fed chief Janet Yellen will worry that wages aren’t rising faster, and the other downbeat elements to the report.

But that may not stop rates rising in the first half of next year.

Alistair writes:

“Welcome as the drop in the unemployment rate is, I very much doubt it will make much difference to the FOMC in its march towards the first rate hike in March or June 2015.

The kindly Ms Yellen will wring her hands over the stubbornly high numbers of long-term unemployed, the part-timers wanting to be full-time and the ‘discouraged workers.’

The realistic Ms Yellen will fret more over the slow growth of average earnings and the sticky participation rate. Then she will conclude there is not much more she can do about any of them.”

Updated at 2.26pm BST

2.21pm BST

Marc Ostwald of ADM Investor Services, says the drop in the US jobless rate is a relief after various weaker data recently.

Here’s his take on the non-farm report:

Key points:

a) Payrolls:

a solid beat at +248k vs. expected 215K, with August revised up by 38K, and July up by 31K

Positives:

1) Government jobs increase +12K

Disappointments:

1) gain paced by Services +207K, notably Retail +35K

2) Leisure/Hospitality +33K, so a continued lack of breadth:

3) Manufacturing just +4K with August revised down to -4K


b) Unemployment Rate:

down to 5.9% from 6.1% will be grist to the mill for the Fed hawks, but the doves will note that the Underemployment Rate at 11.8% while falling from 12.0% is still far too high, especially at this stage of the cycle, though +232K rise in Employment encouraging,though offset by fresh low on the Participation Rate at 62.7% from 62.8%

c) Average Hourly Earnings:

soft at Flat m/m 2.0% y/y - though given that the Payrolls gains were paced by lower paid services jobs, this should not come any surprise.

d) Average Weekly Hours:

Hoorah the headline reading at 34.6 has finally broken the 34.5 ceiling that has been in place since 2012, though Manufacturing Hours only marginally higher - again unsurprising given Manufacturing payrolls.

2.09pm BST

Here comes the reaction to non-farm payroll

With America’s jobless rate now the lowest since summer 2008, there is more pressure on the Fed to normalise monetary policy.

So reckons Marcus Bullus, trading director of MB Capital:

“After this robust number, and decent upward revisions for both July and August, the hawks will once again be circling.

“Policymakers will also be encouraged by the fall in the number of discouraged workers. More people are starting to believe in the economy again and that matters a lot.

However, there’s no avoiding the fact that wages aren’t rising faster:

“Anaemic wage growth continues to be the major conundrum facing markets and policymakers alike.

“You’d expect to see wages rising with more gusto in an improving jobs market, but this just isn’t happening.

Updated at 2.12pm BST

1.59pm BST

These two tweets sum up the non-farm payroll:

1.53pm BST

As the dollar strengthens, the gold price takes another tumble:

1.53pm BST

The dollar is surging, as traders calculate that the fall in the US unemployment rate will prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates before too long.

It has gained over a cent against the pound, to $1.6006.

1.48pm BST

The initial reaction in the financial markets is that this is a strong jobs report.

1.47pm BST

The other disappointment is that America’s labor force participation rate has fallen again, from 62.8% to 62.7%.

That shows that more people have dropped out of the workforce altogether, which helped to drag the overall jobless rate down to 5.9% [because it measures the proportion of people who could be in work, but aren’t]

1.40pm BST

No increase in average hourly earnings

But there is disappointment too - today’s non-farm payroll shows no change in average hourly earnings in September compared with August.

That suggests that the recovery isn’t really feeding into American’s wage packets.

Wall Street economists had been hoping for a 0.2% increase month-on-month.

That left wages 2.0% higher than a year ago.

Updated at 1.51pm BST

1.38pm BST

More good news, last month’s weak non-farm payroll report has been revised higher.

It now shows that 180,000 new jobs were created in August, not the 142,000 first estimated.

And July’s NFP is higher too - up to 243k, from 212k before.

1.32pm BST

US non-farm payroll grows by 248,000

BREAKING: The US non-farm payroll shows that 248,000 new jobs were created across America last month.

That’s a stronger reading than expected.

And the US unemployment rate has fallen to 5.9%, which is the lowest since July 2008.

But it’s not all good news --- the labour force participation rate is a little lower, and average earnings are unchanged.

Lots more details to follow....

1.28pm BST

US unemployment coming up....

Right, time for the last major piece of economic news of the week (hurrah!)

The US non-farm payroll is announced in a few moments, showing how many new jobs were created in America last month.

And economists expect a reading of at least 200,000....

1.19pm BST

Andy Street’s comments about the French economy have already caused a stink in Paris, where a deputy mayor called them “false and idiotic”.

Our correspondent Kim Willsher reports:

Jean-Louis Missika, a deputy Paris mayor in charge of economic development and the attractiveness of Paris to investors, told The Guardian that if Andy Street was joking, perhaps Paris should respond in kind.

“What he says is false and idiotic. As we say, everything excessive is exaggerated, but then it seems French bashing is all the fashion chez vous.

“Factually it’s false because figures show that last year Paris attracted more foreign investment than London, and because Paris is a dynamic city with a quality of service that is often better than in London.”

1.03pm BST

John Lewis MD apologises over French comments

John Lewis’s managing director, Andy Street, has apologised unreservedly for his comments about France.

In a statement, Street said:

“The remarks I made were supposed to be lighthearted views, and tongue in cheek.

On reflection I clearly went too far. I regret the comments, and apologise unreservedly”.

As covered earlier (and all over the UK press), Street describing France as “sclerotic, hopeless and downbeat”.

He made the comments at an event in London, following a trip to Paris where he received a retail award that was “made of plastic and is frankly revolting”.

12.54pm BST

ITV’s Joel Hills is reporting that John Lewis’s MD has now apologised for his French gaffe:

12.39pm BST

Marvel at the squalor of Gare du Nord

The bold declaration by John Lewis’s MD that France was in decline and “finished” continues to reverberate around the media today.

Over on FT Alphaville, Bryce Elder was tickled by Andy Street’s description of Gare du Nord as a “squalid” railway station. Such a contrast with Britain’s own architectural heritage, eh?:

When not doing his bit for Entente cordiale, Bryce also got the City excited by discussing rumours that Tesco might need to raise £3bn from its own shareholders.

We can say with a degree of certainty that a rights issue, £3bn ish probably, is among the options being considered.

That sent Tesco’s shares down another 4.5%; a spokesperson has now said there are “no current plans” for a rights issue.

No mention of future plans, of course....

12.15pm BST

Peter Kellner: Public are losing trust in the powerful

The Institute of Directors had hoping to hear from Alex Salmond at today’s annual conference.

But after the Scottish first minister pulled out, organisers called in Peter Kellner, president of pollsters YouGov, to cover all things Scottish referendum.

And he spoke about how public trust in those in power, including business people, has been eroded.

From the Hall, Katie Allen reports:

Kellner talked about the vote on Scottish independence but also had a message for the audience of business leaders. Providing some welcome context for George Osborne’s earlier complaints about the rise of an anti-business movement, Kellner flagged up the dwindling reputations of those in power - be it in central government, local government or business.

There had been a marked decline in recent years of trust in politics, driven by the weapons of mass destruction (WMD) revelations (or lack thereof) and later on the expenses scandal.

But YouGov had also noted that the reputation of business leaders had declined as a group by tracking various figures in positions of power, Kellner said.

He told the audience that people picked politicians largely based questions around apparent characteristics such as “are they self-serving or public spirited?” Similarly, businesses must ask themselves how their behaviour plays out in public.

If they are judged by stories of “zero-hours, bad pay for cleaners, bad treatment of people in China and Bangladesh... bonuses that appear unforgiveable, tax arrangements that are not ... sociable ... these play like the WMD story on reputations,” Kellner warned.

11.32am BST

George Osborne’s broad message to the Institute of Directors this morning is that stability and tax cuts go hand in hand.

He was speaking just two days after PM David Cameron promised billions of pounds of income tax cuts if the Conservatives win the next election.

But that’s not guaranteed. Political expert Peter Kellner told IoD members that next May’s poll could deliver another coalition.

11.09am BST

Osborne defends UK's push for EU reforms

Asked about the UK government’s push for reforms in the European Union, Osborne sought to emphasise it was not an entirely selfless project.

The chancellor declared:

“We want economic reform in Europe not just for ourselves but for the French, the Spanish [and other countries too].

“We do it not just for ourselves but because we want to live in a prosperous economy,” he said.

On the subject of immigration, increasingly linked in British political debate to the European Union, Osborne appeared to sympathise with some voters’ concerns.

“Free movement of people was never envisaged as freedom to move and claim benefits.”

“It’s important that we find a way through this... there are very real concerns of many members of the British public.”

The IoD, though, is concerned that the clampdown on free movement could hurt the economy, as their head of Europe and trade policy Allie Renison flags up:

Osborne ended with a plea to business to take a stand in what he sees as a new wrangle over the role of enterprise in society.

“That issue felt like it had been resolved when the Berlin wall fell,” he says. “I would urge the business community not to stand on the sidelines.”

And – preaching to the choir somewhat – he told the audience to put the “business argument” against the trade unions, charities and others who - Osborne believed - question the role of business.

Osborne’s own vision is of a business-friendly “low tax economy that delivers prosperity for people for generations to come.”

There endeth the lesson from the Book of Capitalists.....

10.58am BST

10.53am BST

10.49am BST

Osborne: Very, very weak eurozone growth is the biggest near-term risk

Asked by an IoD member from the West Midlands about why the UK still struggled to grow exports, George Osborne said problems in the eurozone, a key market, were a short-term challenge and longer term small and medium sized businesses needed to look further afield.

“Very, very weak growth in the eurozone” is the “biggest near-term risk”, he told the Annual Conference.

Long-term, “we have not connected ourselves enough with the fast growing economies in Asia and the like.”

He said small and medium sized business in the UK appeared “too daunted” about launching into new markets, not the case for small and medium sized businesses in Germany.

For its part, the government has expanded UKTI, he said, and was taking cues from business rather than seeking to come up with export policies out of Whitehall.

“But I am the first to say we have more work to do in this space.”

10.47am BST

10.42am BST

George Osborne also promised that Westminster will meet its pledge to Scotland’s oil and gas industry....

...even if he’s a bit vague on the details.

10.39am BST

The eurozone remains the biggest threat to the UK recovery, Osborne says (perhaps he was thinking of this morning’s poor PMI surveys...)

Updated at 10.47am BST

10.34am BST

George Osborne: We need stability, and help for hard workers

George Osborne is explaining to the IoD annual conferenve how the raft of measures announced this week add up (Katie Allen writes)

The chancellor lays out three points he sees as key to the party’s policies.

Firstly, stability and reassurance that the deficit will come down is
crucial, especially for businesses.

“We have got to reduce the deficit which is still too high” and so he has announced things you would not normally hear ahead of an election, he says, such as a benefits freeze.

Secondly, the Conservatives “unashamedly put business at the heart of our
political message.” Hence competitive business tax rates, he says.

Thirdly, “we have got to make work pay ... That the system works for hard working people, making sure people pay less tax, people on low pay are taken out of tax” and that there is help for people on middle incomes too.

Overall, he says, the government has showed:

“we can achieve both those things, economic stability and low taxes.”

10.27am BST

Simon Walker, IoD director-general, is introducing George Osborne at the Institute of Directors annual conference now.

Walker says the theme of this year’s business jamboree is “game changer” (reports my colleague Katie Allen from the conference).

Walker says much has changed since last year’s meeting, including the creation of half a million jobs and stronger growth than most other advanced economies. But it is also a year when the country almost broke apart.

Part of the reason for that is some people are feeling the effects of the recession rather than the recovery from recession, he says.

Walker also urges members to make sure that business gets across the message that is a force for good....

Updated at 10.31am BST

10.25am BST

George Osborne speaks at the IoD

Heads-up... UK chancellor George Osborne has begun speaking at the Institute of Director’s Annual Convention.....

10.23am BST

John Lewis MD: France is 'finished'

John Lewis, the retail chain, is in the spotlight this morning after its managing director described France as “sclerotic, hopeless and downbeat”.

Andy Street urged British entrepreneurs to flee the country while there’s time, declaring:

If you’ve got investments in French businesses, get them out quickly.”

Street also blasted the Gare du Nord as the “squalor pit of Europe” (?!), in remarks which The Times reckons were ‘tongue in cheek’.

‘Head in hands’ might be more appropriate.

More here: John Lewis boss: ‘France is sclerotic, hopeless and downbeat … it’s finished’

Updated at 11.14am BST

9.51am BST

9.48am BST

Markit: UK recovery may be moderating

The UK services PMI report suggests that Britain’s economy grew by around 0.8% in the third quarter of this year, according to Markit’s Chris Williamson.

He reckons the economy is ‘moderating’, after several strong quarters:

“September’s PMI surveys suggest that the UK most likely enjoyed another spell of above-trend economic growth in the third quarter, but the recovery appears to be losing its legs.

“The PMI surveys are collectively signalling GDP growth of 0.8% in the third quarter, down from 0.9% in the three months to June but still strong by historical standards. However, the pace of expansion hit a six-month low in September and is showing signs of moderating further as we move towards the end of the year.”

9.43am BST

UK service sector growth dips to three-month low

Here comes the UK data....and the news is that Britain’s dominant service sector recorded decent growth in September.

But growth did slow a little, to its slowest in three months, and there are fears that the recent strong recovery is “losing its legs”.

The UK services PMI dipped to a three month low last month, dropping to 58.7 from 60.5 in August. (50 is the cut-off point between expansion and contraction)

Markit says that overall growth remains “sharp”, and the good news is that new business continued to increase. It adds:

  • Capacity remained under pressure, with backlogs of work continuing to increase, and companies were suitably encouraged to add to their payroll numbers.
  • Confidence in the future also helped to support payroll expansion, with latest data showing business expectations at a three-month high.

9.31am BST

Markit: Eurozone GDP growth will be modest

September’s poor PMI surveys show that eurozone economic growth in the last quarter was weak, says Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit:

“The PMI suggests the eurozone economy remained stuck in a rut in the third quarter. After GDP stagnated in the second quarter, we can only expect modest growth of 0.2-0.3% in the third quarter based on these survey readings, with momentum being lost as we head into the final quarter of the year.

There are some pockets of growth:

Ireland’s economy is recovering strongly, Spain is seeing a still-robust upturn and the German service sector is providing an important prop to growth in the region as a whole. But the overall picture is one of a euro area economy that is struggling against multiple headwinds. These include a lack of domestic demand in many countries, subdued bank lending, sanctions with Russia and a reluctance of companies to expand in the face of an uncertain economic outlook.

And if things don’t improve, there will be more pressure on the European Central Bank to “broaden the scope of its planned asset purchases” to buy riskier assets and even sovereign debt, Williamson concludes.

9.25am BST

Here’s a reminder of this morning’s data:

Updated at 9.27am BST

9.24am BST

Eurozone growth wanes as downturns in France and Italy continue

Europe’s economic woes have deepened, with private sector growth slowing to the lowest rate in 10 months.

That’s the conclusions of this morning’s data, and surveys earlier this week.

Markit’s Eurozone PMI composite output index, which tracks activity across thousands of firms, has fallen to a ten-month low of 52.0 in September, down from 52.5 in August.

Markit pulls no punches, saying:

The ongoing malaise in the eurozone economy continued at the end of the third quarter, with the latest PMI data showing a further waning of output and new order growth.

As covered earlier in the blog, Italy (details) and France (details) are the two main worries.

France saw solid declines in both manufacturing production and service sector activity. The contraction in Italy was centred on the service sector, as manufacturing output expanded.

The data is also a blow to hopes that Europe’s employment crisis might be improving.

Staffing levels fell at the steepest pace for 16 months in France. Job creation accelerated in Germany, but slowed in Ireland and Spain. Headcounts stabilised in Italy, following a slight decrease in August.

Reaction to follow....

9.16am BST

9.06am BST

Germany's service sector keeps growing

Germany’s service firms have defied the slowdown in France, Italy and Spain, with activity growing at a faster rate.

The German services PMI rose to 55.7 in September, up from 54.9 in August, showing growth accelerated.

Activity and new order growth picked up after dipping in August.

But it’s not all good news. Confidence towards the business outlook among German firms falls to 15-month low.

Markit’s Oliver Kolodseike says:

companies expect the introduction of a national minimum wage in January 2015 to have at least some negative effect on economic growth.

Russian sanctions and the weak eurozone economy may be a factor.

9.00am BST

French service sector shrinks

France’s economy has moved deeper into trouble too.

Its service sector contracted in September for the first time in three months, according to Markit, dragging the wider French private sector into contraction too.

Service sector firms reported a fall in new business, and an increase in staff layoffs.

Alarmingly, French service sector firms cut staffing levels at the sharpest rate in 17 months.

Markit says:

There were reports from the survey panel linking job losses to company restructuring policies and, in some cases, decisions not to replace voluntary leavers.

Jack Kennedy, senior economist at Markit, adds:

“September’s PMI data rounded off another disappointing quarter for the French private sector economy.

Based on the survey’s activity readings, GDP still looks to be tracking close to stagnation, continuing the stalling performance seen since the start of the year. Jobs across the private sector were cut at the sharpest rate for 16 months in September, suggesting that companies are braced for a prolonged period of weakness.”

8.55am BST

8.52am BST

Italian service sector shrinks again

And this is worrying too! Italy’s service sector suffered a deeper contraction than expected last month.

Markit’s Italian services sector PMI fell to 48.8, down from August’s reading of 49.8.

That shows a sharper drop in activity, indicating that Italy’s service sector remained in contraction at the end of the third quarter,

Markit reports that new business fell, due to “a general weakening of client demand in September”.

Phil Smith, economist at Markit, says the reading puts “another dent in the hopes of the [Italian] economy climbing out of recession in the third quarter”.

“Weakness in demand was evident as new business intakes went down another notch, which in turn pressured businesses into making further notable reductions to their charges. Manufacturers likewise reduced their output prices, suggesting broad-based deflationary forces.

“A halt in service sector job cuts and improved business sentiment were the relatively positive takeaways from the latest data, with the former a step in the right direction in terms of seeing demand-side trends improve.”

8.46am BST

Spain's service sector growth hits three-month low

Now this is worrying... growth in the Spanish service sector has slowed, and new orders grew at the lowest rate in almost a year.

Spain’s recent revival tailed off last month, according to data firm Markit, with employment levels broadly unchanged.

Its Spanish services PMI fell sharply to 55.8 in September from 58.1 in August; that still shows growth, but not as robust. It’s the slowest rise in activity for three months.

Andrew Harker, senior economist at Markit, doesn’t sound too alarmed, predicting that Spain’s economy still grew solidly in the last quarter.

But still....

“There were signs of a growth slowdown in the Spanish service sector at the end of Q3, particularly with regards to new business which increased at the weakest pace for almost a year. There was also disappointing news on the employment front, with the recent spell of job creation coming to an end.

8.30am BST

Russian firms only manage slow growth

Russia’s private sector only managed to post small growth last month, according to HSBC’s survey of the sector.

The Russian composite PMI slid to just 50.9, close to the 50-point mark showing stagnation. Firms reported falling optimism, with business expectations close to their lowest point since the financial crisis began.

Employment levels fell for the 15th month running, and firms reported “weakening demand, a lack of funds among clients and weak international demand”.

Alexander Morozov, HSBC’s chief economist for Russia, warned that the country is sliding into recession:

Overall, the Russian economy must have continued very slow growth in September amid strong and intensified cost pressures and increasing uncertainties about future business development.

Such weak mechanical growth is better than the absence of growth, but we do not see drivers for stronger growth while downside risks to growth are abundant. Lower oil prices and persistent decline in fixed investment are just few of them. A mild recession remains our base case scenario for the coming quarters.

Here’s the full report.

Updated at 8.39am BST

8.20am BST

Irish service sector keeps growing

Ireland’s recovery from the depths of its austerity slump continues, with service sector firms reporting the 26th month of consecutive growth.

Investec’s monthly PMI survey, based on interviews with purchasing managers at Irish firms, found that new business had expanded at its fastest since May 2006.

Irish firms are also more confidence, with 60% expecting activity to rise in the next year.

Philip O’Sullivan, Chief Economist at Investec Ireland, says Ireland is benefiting from the recovery in the UK economy:

Panellists reported that the growth in New Business was a result of clients’ increased willingness to commit to new projects given signs of improvement in the Irish economy.

Growth in New Export Business also accelerated during September, with the UK cited as a particular source of strength.

The overall Service sector PMI rose to 62.5 in September, showing strong growth, after August’s 62.4.

8.13am BST

Chinese service sector growth hits eight-month low

There’s gloomy news from China overnight -- its services sector has grown at the slowest pace in eight month, partly due to the weakening housing market.

Official figures showed that new orders actually shrank in September, for the first time since the collapse of Lehman Brothers.

The official non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) fell to 54.0 in September from 54.4 in August, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

That still shows growth, but the slowest since January, adding to concerns that the Chinese economy is slowing.

Today’s report also shows that China’s real estate sector shrank in September, as did the aviation and logistics sectors.

Cai Jin, the vice-chairman of China Federation of Logistics and Purchasing, reckons China’s property slide may have bottomed out:

Business activities in the property market have stabilized at low levels but stayed within the contractionary area, suggesting overall activities remained sluggish.”

7.56am BST

The Agenda: Service sector data and US unemployment

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, business and the eurozone.

After yesterday’s nervy sell-off, Europe’s stock markets are expected to bounce back a little today as traders prepare for the latest US jobs report.

September’s non-farm payroll, due at 1.30pm BST, is expected to show that hiring picked up again after just 142,000 or so new jobs were created in August.

And a positive jobs report is likely to drive investors to conclude that the US Federal Reserve will move closer to its first interest rate hike since the crisis began.

Stan Shamu, IG’s man in Melbourne, sets the scene:

After recent comments by Fed members who increasingly sound more hawkish, this week’s non-farm payrolls data will carry significant weight and go a long way towards shaping rate hike expectations.

After a slump the previous month (142,000), non-farm payrolls are expected to bounce back strongly with a reading north of 200,000. Analysts feel a strong reading today could then see the Fed drop its ‘considerable time’ reference as far as rates lift-off is concerned.

This month’s FOMC meeting will also be when QE wraps up and therefore is likely to be pivotal for the greenback.

In the meantime, we’ll be watching the latest service sector data from Europe for signs that the economy may be recovering.

Economists expect to see the Italy and France’s service sectors both contracted again last month, while firms in Germany and the UK report stronger growth. We’ll have all the data by 9.30am BST.....

Updated at 8.04am BST
